With Lane Closing For Arts and Sciences School

The main southbound lane
on Charles Street, scene of a
number of accidents last year,
will now operate only from 7 to
9 am Monday through Friday
and during stadium events.
Hopkins, the Charles Village
Community Association and
the City Department of Transit and Traffic have worked
together for nearly a year to
close the lane in an effort to
prevent more accidents, the last
of which occurred this summer.
"Area pedestrian accidents
have occurred most frequently
in this southbound lane and
we've agreed that by restricting
its use we'll improve safety,"
said Jim Causey, commissioner
pf Transit and Traffic, in an

August 31 press release.
The closing has been effected
by temporary barricades, traffic signs and traffic and transit
officials guiding motorists.
"The signs are there, the barricades are there, and people
are passing out flyers to motorists to advise them of the
change," said Jon Lana, last
year's Chairman of Student
Life. "All in all, we're very
satisfied with the city's action."

The temporary signs, barricades, and officials will be
replaced later this year by
custom-made, large, overhead
lane control signals with exceptionally bright fiber optic lights
for added safety.

What Will Council Do?
by Maureen Freed
Student governments in
many universities are facing the
problem of student disinterest
in their activities. Lack of student enthusiasm for, and involvement in, student government efforts is often blamed for
its failures.
Paradoxically, apathetic candidates are now running for office, claiming that their unconcern is representative of student attitudes. Eric Fink led the
GASP (Generally Apathetic
Students Party) in the Hopkins
Student Council elections last
year. Similar parties have
sprung up at many universities.
The University of Utah held
elections recently for its legislative assembly. Two parties
with platforms of apathy offered candidates—the Burial
Party, which ran on the platform of reducing the budget
available for student activities,
and the KOBOL (Krush Apathetic Bureaucracy) Party,
which ran on a platform of
abolishing parts of student
government altogether.
Evidently, students in many
college campuses don't think
that their student representatives are doing much to
justify their existence.
But it's a mistake to conclude
that students are necessarily
and irrevocably disinterested in
/what the Student Council is doing. There are a lot of things
students definitely do give a
damn about. Some examples—
their grades, the state of their
finances and their night life.
When student government
begins to have an impact in
areas close to students, those
students will care about what
student government is doing.
This is what the Johns
Hopkins Student Council will
attempt over the coming year.
We.will attack first the questions which relate directly to a
large number of students. We
want to make changes which
will have an immediate impact
and which will have that impact
in the near future.
This does not mean we have
to be short-sighted. It means
that we have to focus our
priorities in a rational and efficient manner.
This philosphy will guide us*
in setting the agenda for Student Council and its committees in the coming year.
The Housing Committee will

be led by Steve Segreto, who
was at the forefront of the
McCoy rents controversy last
year. As a result of Steve's efforts, along with those of other
members of last year's Housing
Committee, McCoy rents paid
by many freshmen were
lowered.
Jon Lana will lead the Committee on Education. Last year,
Jon chaired the Student Life
Committee, which was responsible for changes in the traffic
pattern on Charles Street. Application of his practical, goaloriented approach to education
policy will mean a tremendous
improvement in the operation
of this important committee.
The Career Advising Committee, to be chaired by Beth
Wallen, will expand its focus
somewhat over previous years.
The important career advising
forums will, of course, be continued. The Committee will
also go beyond the traditional
forums to undertake evaluation
of a broad range of career
development resources at
Hopkins.
Tracy Maginity will serve as
Chairman of the Student Life
Committee, undertaking a wide
variety of important projects.
I am confident that these
people can provide the strong
leadership the Student Council
committees need. All are committed to establishing practical
and meaningful agendas for the
coming year. And together they
will accomplish a great deal for
the Hopkins undergraduate
community
The efforts of these important committees will be taking
place within the framework of

and the student body. There

Student Council Response

by Maureen Freed
Student governments in
many universities are facing the
problem of student disinterest
in their activities. Lack of student enthusiasm for, and involvement in, student government efforts is often blamed for
its failures.
Paradoxically, apathetic candidates are now running for office, claiming that their unconcern is representative of student attitudes. Eric Fink led the
GASP (Generally Apathetic
Students Party) in the Hopkins
Student Council elections last
year. Similar parties have
sprung up at many universities.
The University of Utah held
elections recently for its legislative assembly. Two parties
with platforms of apathy offered candidates—the Burial
Party, which ran on the platform of reducing the budget
available for student activities,
and the KOBOL (Krush Apathetic Bureaucracy) Party,
which ran on a platform of
abolishing parts of student
government altogether.
Evidently, students in many
college campuses don't think
that their student representatives are doing much to
justify their existence.
But it's a mistake to conclude
that students are necessarily
and irrevocably disinterested in
/what the Student Council is doing. There are a lot of things
students definitely do give a
damn about. Some examples—
their grades, the state of their
finances and their night life.
When student government
begins to have an impact in
areas close to students, those
students will care about what
student government is doing.
This is what the Johns
Hopkins Student Council will
attempt over the coming year.
We.will attack first the questions which relate directly to a
large number of students. We
want to make changes which
will have an immediate impact
and which will have that impact
in the near future.
This does not mean we have
to be short-sighted. It means
that we have to focus our
priorities in a rational and efficient manner.
This philosphy will guide us*
in setting the agenda for Student Council and its committees in the coming year.

be led by Steve Segreto, who
was at the forefront of the
McCoy rents controversy last
year. As a result of Steve's efforts, along with those of other

lowered.

of this important committee.

Wallen, will expand its focus

also go beyond the traditional

Hopkins.
Tracy Maginity will serve as
